courseDescription: Overview of the principles, practices, and science of public health in the world. This course focuses on origins, evolution, structure and administration of public health science. Exploration and discussion of the core functions of public health - biostatistics, environmental sciences, epidemiology, health policy and management sciences, and social and behavioral sciences - will be instructed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding health policy and management sciences
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and exploration of core public health functions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of health data
Critical evaluation of health policies and strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in public health administration

courseDescription: An introduction to the chemical, physical and biological factors affecting human health and well-being. The emphasis is on application of controls to prevent disease and maximize environmental quality. Cross-listed with ENVH 301.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of chemical, physical and biological factors affecting human health
Application of controls to maximize environmental quality
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex health and environmental concepts to a non-technical audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of various environmental factors on human health
Developing strategies for disease prevention and environmental quality improvement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading initiatives for disease prevention and environmental improvement

courseDescription: Course designed especially for those entering the health education or health care field, covering the physiology of each of the major body systems as a basis for understanding those aspects of its function that reflect the importance of various nutrients.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physiology of major body systems
Knowledge of the importance of various nutrients
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex physiological processes
Communication of nutritional concepts to others in the health education or health care field
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of nutrients on body systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on nutrition and health care

courseDescription: This course will explore the history of health equity and disability and how prejudice and discrimination against people with disabilities impact health. Students will learn how to apply health equity frameworks, theories, and research to address disability-specific models of health disparities and to achieve health equity in populations with disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching disability-specific models of health disparities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and interpreting prejudice and discrimination
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of discrimination on health
Applying theories to address health disparities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promoting health equity in populations with disabilities

courseDescription: This course provides a population-based approach to professional work in disease management, chronic care management and politics, in addition to students studying public health, health policy, quality and patient safety, health care administration, medicine, nursing, pharmacy, social work and other related clinical professions.

This course introduces students to health-care delivery systems of non-Western countries, specifically developing countries. The various factors that influence health-care planning and delivery of health services are addressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of health services in non-Western and developing countries
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying health service delivery methods to diverse contexts

courseDescription: The uniqueness of the U.S. healthcare delivery system will be explored in terms of a systems framework and its complexity. The basic characteristics that differentiate the U.S. healthcare delivery system from that of other countries will be presented. An understanding of the U.S. health care system has specific implications for health services managers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the U.S. healthcare delivery system
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of health care system complexities
Presentation of health care system characteristics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the U.S. healthcare system
Evaluation of differences between international healthcare systems

courseDescription: Study of selected topics.

courseTitle: Social and Behavioral Aspects of Public Health
courseDescription: The course will emphasize the importance of social context and cultural construction, social and behavioral foundations of public health and examine current issues in health from a social and behavioral sciences perspective. The course uses a social ecological framework to address multilevel influences on health and enlarge the dominant 'risk factor' approach to health behavior.  This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding of cultural and social context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social and behavioral foundations
Evaluation and understanding of the social ecological framework
Identification of multilevel influences on health

courseDescription: This course will teach students the applications of multidisciplinary competencies towards solving human health challenges. The course will identify all areas of global health issues that require human, veterinary and environmental applications for solutions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of human, veterinary and environmental health issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Formulating solutions for human health challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in problem-solving for health challenges

courseDescription: The course will introduce students to the main theories of leadership in public health covering key concepts and strategies using the six levels of leadership framework. The course will explore how individual, team, organizational, community, professional and global leadership impact population and public health.

courseTitle: Health, Culture and Diversity-Reducing Disparities in Public Health
courseDescription: The course will introduce students to the main theories of culture, health and diversity and examines what is meant by culture, the ways in which culture intersects with health issues, how public health efforts can benefit by understanding and working with cultural processes, and a brief selection of conceptual tools and research methods that are useful in identifying relationships between culture and health. The course will also include practical guidelines for incorporating cultural understanding in public health settings and examples of programs where that has occurred.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying relationships between culture and health
Applying cultural understanding in public health settings
Research methods in cultural health studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with diverse cultural groups
Work with cultural processes in public health settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Theoretical analysis of culture and health
Application of cultural theories in public health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing cultural understanding in public health programs
Guiding public health efforts with cultural understanding
Designing and managing culturally-sensitive public health programs

courseDescription: Identifies major issues and problems in meeting health care needs of the aged. Emphasis on role of social assets and supports in determining effects of life changes on the aging process.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis for health care needs
Utilizing digital platforms for social support
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying health care needs of the aged
Analyzing effects of life changes on the aging process
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading support teams for elderly care

courseTitle: Community Health Resources and Health Promotion
courseDescription: Designed to provide information about community health resources. This is a writing intensive course.
This course covers financial management functions in healthcare organizations including operating and capital budgeting processes along with budgeting and financial controls.

This course focuses on health services research and its assessment abilities and application in health care and public health. Topics include the use of EXCEL, SAS, and SPSS to analyze data. An exploration of the issues and challenges of health services research for health related organizations and other organizations. Statistical procedures and practices will also be conducted.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of statistical procedures and practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment abilities application in health care and public health
Addressing issues and challenges in health services research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of research methods to health related organizations

courseDescription: An introductory course in the principles and practices of epidemiology and the application of statistical and mathematical design and analysis of health research studies for the understanding and control of population health and disease with emphasis on environmental applications.  Cross-listed with ENVH 448.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of statistical and mathematical design
Understanding and control of population health and disease
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying epidemiological principles in environmental health

courseDescription: A review of the principles and practice of administering public and community health organizations and programs at federal, state, and local levels. Constitutional, statutory and administrative bases for organizing and conducting public/community health programs will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of federal, state, and local health organizations
Familiarity with constitutional, statutory and administrative bases for health programs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with various health organization levels
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of public/community health program efficiencies
Problem-solving in public health administration context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in public and community health settings
Understanding and implementation of health administrative bases

courseDescription: This course will blend theory and application of epidemiology. This course will also provide a comprehensive introduction to epidemiology and explain how to use epidemiological concepts and tools to improve decisions about the management of health services.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decisions making in health services management

courseDescription: This course will explore both health policy and the politics of health. Students will develop an understanding of the systematic and analytical framework for developing health and health care policy issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Systematic analysis of health care issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical framework for health care policy issues
Problem solving in health policy context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and prioritizing health care issues

courseDescription: The internship will allow a student new to the health administration field or public health field to complete a capstone internship to gain entry skills for a beginning career pathway in the profession. The course is intended to provide field experience and assimilation of the theoretical aspects learned in the coursework in a practical/work setting. A minimum of 200 hours is required for the 3-credit internship.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and adaptation to work settings

courseDescription: This course provides a basic understanding of marketing in a health care setting. It will cover the following: the history of marketing in a health care setting, health care markets, marketing techniques, and leadership skills in managing and supporting the marketing efforts.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effectiveness of marketing techniques
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in supporting and implementing marketing strategies

courseDescription: This course provides the students with a basic knowledge of health law and examines legal issues confronting health services administrators in various health care environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with legal issues in healthcare environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with health services administrators
Negotiation and resolution of legal issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying potential legal issues in healthcare settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Navigating legal aspects of healthcare administration
Leading discussions on health law issues

courseDescription: This course focuses on healthcare informatics (information systems) and applications in health care organizations. It provides an overview of health information system concepts, management, and integration of technology in healthcare organizations.
This course provides the opportunity for the study of selected topics in public/community health, including informatics, under the supervision of a faculty member.

Introduces students to 21st century environmental health issues and challenges, and examines how they affect health in the region, nation and world. Topics include: air/water quality, food safety and food-borne illness, antibiotic resistance, emergency preparedness and response, sea level rise, vulnerable populations, radiation safety and health, pediatric environmental health, tick-borne illness, hazardous substances, environmental health policy and practice, and environmental risk communication.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of food safety and food-borne illness
Understanding of emergency preparedness and response
Understanding of radiation safety and health
Understanding of environmental health policy and practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementation of environmental health policy and practice

courseTitle: Environmental Health Law, Justice and Governance
courseDescription: An overview of environmental health law and governance at the local, state, federal and international levels. Students examine the environmental health policy-making process and how laws, regulations and treaties are made and implemented. Students also will be familiarized with U.S. environmental public health statutes, key institutions and agencies, current controversies, issues of environmental justice, and major international treaties related to environmental health.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of environmental health law and governance
Knowledge of U.S. environmental public health statutes
Familiarity with major international environmental health treaties
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss current controversies in environmental health
Ability to communicate issues of environmental justice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of law, regulations, and treaties
Critical examination of environmental health policy-making process
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of key institutions and agencies in environmental health
Ability to navigate and understand environmental health governance structures

courseDescription: Provides an introduction to the multidisciplinary field of public health by examining the history, structure and functions of the public health system.  Course is organized around the three core functions of public health: assessment, policy development and assurance while focusing on elements of the basic public health disciplines.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in public health contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning and organization in public health

courseTitle: Social and Behavioral Sciences for Public Health
courseDescription: Students will learn about different theoretical perspectives and how to apply appropriate social and behavioral models to public health programs. Topics discussed include social inequalities in health status related to culture, race, social class, gender, and the critical intersection between social risk factors, behavioral risk factors, and the development and implementation of public health interventions.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding cultural, racial, and gender disparities in health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social inequalities in health status
Development and implementation of public health interventions
Analyzing interaction between social and behavioral risk factors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing public health programs

courseDescription: This is a course in research methods that will provide an overview of the basic principles of research design, methods, measurement, data collection and data management in the field of public health. Students will learn the differences between quantitative, qualitative and mixed-methods approaches to public health research, as well as how to formulate and evaluate research questions.

Students will learn the practice of systems thinking, which includes the ability to integrate multiple perspectives and synthesize them into a framework or model that encompasses the various ways in which a system might react to policy choices.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of multiple perspectives into a single framework

courseTitle: Environmental and Occupational Health Risk Assessment
courseDescription: This course is an introduction to quantitative and qualitative risk analysis and examines the fundamental aspects of risk, focusing on environmental, occupational, and public health risk. Hazard identification, exposure assessment, dose-response evaluation, risk characterization, and risk communication are emphasized.

This course provides an introduction to the topic of global health disparities through an in‐depth examination and discussion of the relationship between social injustice and inequitable health outcomes. Students will be introduced to the social and environmental determinants of health disparities and the pathways and mechanisms leading to inequitable health outcomes in vulnerable groups, as well as strategies for addressing these determinants to improve health.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of social and environmental determinants
Understanding mechanisms leading to inequitable health outcomes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of strategies for addressing health disparities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of health disparities
Critical evaluation of social injustice issues
Development of strategies to improve health outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and execution of health improvement strategies
Leadership in addressing social injustice and health disparities

courseDescription: An introduction to the fundamentals of toxicology with emphasis on the interaction of environmental and industrial chemicals with humans are studied. Exposure, dose response, kinetics and distribution of toxicants, metabolism of toxic agents, factors that affect toxicity and introductory chemical carcinogenesis are discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of environmental and industrial chemicals
Knowledge of dose response, kinetics and distribution of toxicants

courseDescription: This course provides a culminating learning experience in the MPH curriculum, which gives students the opportunity to demonstrate integration of foundational and concentration competencies and to apply the knowledge and skills achieved in their study of public health. The learning outcome is the demonstrated mastery, via course assignments, of core public health and discipline- or concentration-specific competencies.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical assessment of public health situations

courseDescription: This course covers basic epidemiologic methods and research study design such as case-control and cohort studies, randomized trials, risk estimation, and causal inferences. Content also covers the use of epidemiology in public health practice, links to health policy, and the factors and associations determining the distribution of disease in the population.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of epidemiology in public health practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guiding public health practice based on epidemiological findings

courseDescription: The goal of this course is to guide students with a public health perspective to develop skills to identify and analyze environmental health problems globally. It is designed to provide knowledge on recognizing and evaluating major environmental health issues and risk factors in developed and developing countries by using group discussions and real-life case studies.

This course examines the interrelationships between individual and societal decisions and the global environment, and analyzes the consequences these interrelationships have for public health and sustainability. The course will review food, environmental quality, climate variability, sea-level rise and public health, homes-workplaces-communities, environmental health and sustainability, in the region, the nation and around the world
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of climate variability and sea-level rise
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of public health and sustainability issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of societal decisions' impact on the environment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of sustainable homes, workplaces, and communities
